metadata.titleEn: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (automatic weather station of mixed forest station, 2023)
metadata.description:
This dataset includes data recorded by the Heihe integrated observatory network obtained from the automatic weather station (AWS) at the Sidaoqiao mixed forest station from January 1 to December 31, 2023. The site (101.134° E, 41.990° N) was located on a tamarix and populous forest (Tamarix chinensis Lour. and Populus euphratica Olivier.) surface in the Sidaoqiao, Dalaihubu Town, Ejin Banner, Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region. The elevation is 874 m. The installation heights and orientations of different sensors and measured quantities were as follows: air temperature and humidity profile (28 m, north), wind speed and direction profile (28 m, north), air pressure (in tamper box), rain gauge (28 m, south), four-component radiometer (24 m, south), two infrared temperature sensors (24 m, south, vertically downward), two photosynthetically active radiation (24 m, south, one vertically upward and one vertically downward), soil heat flux (HFP01; 3 duplicates, -0.06 m), soil temperature profile (0, -0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.6, -1.0, -1.6, -2.0, -2.4 m), and soil moisture profile (-0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.6, -1.0, -1.6, -2.0, -2.4 m).
The observations included the following: air temperature and humidity (Ta_28 m; RH_28 m) (℃ and %, respectively), wind speed (Ws_28 m) (m/s), wind direction (WD_28 m) (°), air pressure (press) (hpa), precipitation (rain) (mm), four-component radiation (DR, incoming shortwave radiation; UR, outgoing shortwave radiation; DLR_Cor, incoming longwave radiation; ULR_Cor, outgoing longwave radiation; Rn, net radiation) (W/m^2), infrared temperature (IRT_1 and IRT_2) (℃), photosynthetically active radiation of upward and downward (PAR_up and PAR_down) (μmol/ (s m^2)), soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2 and Gs_3) (W/m^2), soil temperature (Ts_0 cm, Ts_2 cm, Ts_4 cm, Ts_10 cm, Ts_20 cm, Ts_40 cm, Ts_60 cm, Ts_100, Ts_160, Ts_200, Ts_240 cm) (℃), and soil moisture (Ms_2 cm, Ms_4 cm, Ms_10 cm, Ms_20 cm, Ms_40 cm, Ms_60 cm, Ms_100, Ms_160, Ms_200, Ms_240 cm) (%, volumetric water content).
The data processing and quality control steps were as follows: (1) The AWS data were averaged over intervals of 10 min for a total of 144 records per day. The missing data were denoted by -6999. (2) Data in duplicate records were rejected. (3) Unphysical data were rejected. (4) The data marked in red are problematic data. (5) The format of the date and time was unified, and the date and time were collected in the same column, for example, date and time: 2023-9-10 10:30. (6) Finally, the naming convention was AWS+ site no. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) and Liu et al. (2023).

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to monitor energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used in oasis–desert ecosystems involves using an eddy covariance system and scintillometer to acquire half-hourly turbulent flux data. Additionally, automatic weather stations are employed to observe hydrometeorological data with a 10-minute average period.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge that inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing, which may affect data collection efforts?
Example.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas, such as the Tarim River basin, face challenges like the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent occurrence of dust storms. These environmental issues can complicate data collection efforts.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset that includes comprehensive observational data on hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters in arid regions?
Example.Answer: A dataset that includes comprehensive observational data on hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters can be found in the middle and lower reaches of the Heihe River Basin, which consist of energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes, and auxiliary data collected from superstations and ordinary stations since 2012.

Feature Specification.Question: What characteristics define a comprehensive observational network for monitoring surface processes in arid regions?
Feature Specification.Answer: automated meteorological stations, air temperature, relative humidity, atmospheric pressure, precipitation, wind speed and direction, radiation components, surface radiation temperature, soil heat flux, soil temperature, soil moisture, sensors positioned at specific heights and depths, rigorous data processing, quality control procedures

Feature Specification.Question: What are the key features of data quality control processes in meteorological datasets?
Feature Specification.Answer: consistent number of data points per day, specific indicators for missing data, removal of duplicate records, elimination of data exceeding physical or instrumental limits, marking of questionable data, standardized date and time formats

Feature Specification.Question: What specific attributes are considered when collecting data on soil properties in oasis-desert areas?
Feature Specification.Answer: soil temperature at various depths, soil moisture content, soil heat flux

Definition.Question: What is the meaning of 'comprehensive observation network' in the context of meteorological data collection?
Definition.Answer: A 'comprehensive observation network' in meteorological data collection refers to a system of stations and sensors that gather a wide array of environmental data across different variables and locations. In this context, it includes measurements of air temperature, humidity, soil moisture, radiation, and other climatic factors to provide a holistic understanding of surface processes.

Comparison.Question: How do data collection techniques for soil moisture and temperature in the Heihe River Basin compare to those used in other arid regions?
Comparison.Answer: The data collection techniques for soil moisture and temperature in the Heihe River Basin involve embedding soil temperature and moisture probes at various depths up to 240 cm. These methods are similar to those used in other arid regions where soil profiles are critical. However, the specific depths and frequency of data collection (every 10 minutes) may vary compared to other regions.

Interpretation.Question: How might the observed data on air temperature and humidity from an automatic weather station contribute to understanding climate trends in arid and semi-arid regions?
Interpretation.Answer: The observed data on air temperature and humidity can help identify patterns and changes over time, which are essential for understanding how climate trends are affecting arid and semi-arid regions. Such data can reveal the impact of climate change on oasis–desert systems and inform strategies for sustainable development and ecological balance.

Interpretation.Question: What can the patterns in soil temperature and moisture data reveal about the underlying soil and vegetation interactions in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Interpretation.Answer: Patterns in soil temperature and moisture data can provide insights into the interactions between soil and vegetation, such as water retention capacity, root zone dynamics, and the effects of temperature on vegetation growth. These interactions are crucial for maintaining the ecological stability and productivity of oasis–desert ecosystems.

Interpretation.Question: How do the methods of data processing and quality control affect the reliability and usability of meteorological and flux datasets in studying oasis–desert systems?
Interpretation.Answer: Data processing and quality control methods, such as ensuring data completeness, removing duplicates, and discarding physically unrealistic values, significantly enhance the reliability and usability of datasets. These methods ensure that the data accurately represents the studied phenomena, allowing for more precise modeling and analysis of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in oasis–desert systems.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the necessity of using both field and remote-sensing observations for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange studies in oasis–desert areas?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Extensive studies have shown that understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas requires a combination of field and remote-sensing observations to capture the complex interactions and dynamics within these ecosystems. This approach is critical for achieving goals like carbon peaking and carbon neutrality, as well as supporting ecological stability and sustainable development.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is long-term data collection crucial for understanding the interactions between oasis and desert systems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Long-term observations are indispensable for recognizing oasis–desert interactions because they provide quantitative insights into the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange processes. This understanding is significant for protecting the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases and is necessary to maintain a balance between oasis and desert systems.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What challenges are faced in data collection within inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas face ecological degradation challenges, such as drying rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These conditions complicate data collection efforts and impact the accuracy and comprehensiveness of datasets.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of implementing consistent quality control measures on long-term meteorological data collection in arid and semi-arid regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Implementing consistent quality control measures on long-term meteorological data collection can lead to more accurate and reliable datasets, which are crucial for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems. This reliability can support achieving sustainable development goals and ensuring ecological security in these regions.

Causal Consequence.Question: What might be the implications of integrating eddy covariance system data with traditional meteorological observations for carbon cycle studies in arid regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating eddy covariance system data with traditional meteorological observations can enhance carbon cycle studies by offering a comprehensive view of carbon and methane fluxes in oasis–desert systems. This integration allows for a more detailed quantitative understanding of carbon sinks and sources, contributing to carbon balance assessments and informing strategies for carbon neutrality in these regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives behind establishing automatic weather stations for collecting meteorological data in arid and semi-arid regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to understand the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems, which is crucial for achieving sustainable oasis development, carbon peaking, and carbon neutrality in these areas.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to maintain long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in oasis–desert areas?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Long-term observations are essential for recognizing oasis–desert interactions and protecting the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases. They also support ecological security and sustainable development goals.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are used to ensure data quality and accuracy when collecting meteorological data in complex ecological environments like mixed forest stations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Data quality and accuracy are ensured by several procedures: ensuring daily 144 data points (every 10 minutes), marking missing data with -6999, removing duplicate records, deleting data that significantly exceed physical meanings or instrument ranges, marking questionable data in red, and standardizing date and time formats.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can automatic weather stations be effectively utilized to monitor energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Automatic weather stations can be used by equipping them with sensors for air temperature, humidity, wind speed and direction, radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles, alongside air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles. These stations collect data with a 10-minute average period, and the data is further processed and quality controlled for use in analyzing energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the recommended steps for implementing data processing and quality control in datasets involving soil temperature and moisture measurements in desert regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Data processing involves collecting measurements at various depths (e.g., soil temperature at depths from 0cm to 240cm, soil moisture at depths from 2cm to 240cm) and ensuring data quality through daily checks for completeness, removing duplicates, and deleting outliers. Questionable data is flagged, and data is formatted consistently for date and time. These steps help in maintaining the integrity and usefulness of the datasets.

Enablement.Question: What data collection methods enable the observation of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: Long-term observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis-desert systems, including half-hourly turbulent flux data acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer, as well as hydrometeorological data observed from automatic weather stations with a 10-minute average period, enable the observation of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of various sensor technologies enable comprehensive meteorological data collection in mixed forest ecosystems of arid regions?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of sensors such as air temperature and humidity sensors, barometers, rain gauges, wind speed and direction sensors, radiometers, infrared thermometers, and soil moisture and temperature probes enables comprehensive meteorological data collection by providing diverse data points including air temperature, humidity, pressure, precipitation, wind speed, and soil conditions.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in ensuring the quality control of datasets collected from oasis–desert ecosystems over long-term periods?
Expectation.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms. These challenges can complicate the quality control process for datasets by introducing variability and potential data gaps over long-term periods.

Expectation.Question: Why is it critical to maintain a balance in oasis–desert systems when collecting energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange data?
Expectation.Answer: Maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems is critical to achieve sustainable oasis development. A quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis.

Expectation.Question: Why is long-term data collection crucial for understanding oasis–desert interactions and supporting sustainable ecological practices?
Expectation.Answer: Long-term observations are indispensable for achieving a quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas. This understanding is crucial to recognize oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges in maintaining long-term observational datasets in remote oasis-desert systems, and how can researchers address these challenges?
Judgmental.Answer: Potential challenges include equipment maintenance, data quality control, and environmental harshness affecting sensor performance. Researchers can address these by implementing robust data processing procedures, regular maintenance schedules, and remote monitoring systems to ensure data integrity and continuity over long periods.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways might data collection methods for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert areas be refined to better support sustainable development goals?
Judgmental.Answer: Data collection methods can be refined by incorporating advanced technologies such as high-resolution satellite imagery and machine learning algorithms to enhance the spatial and temporal resolution of datasets. Additionally, integrating socio-economic data with environmental observations can provide a more holistic approach to sustainable development in oasis-desert areas.
